items.content_html:
Description

  • s/Things that trigger negotiation/Things that require negotiation/ to avoid inferring replaceTrack triggers renegotiation.
  • Clarify that resolution changes often work with replaceTrack (e.g. front/back cameras are a major use case and rarely the same dimensions)

Motivation

Clarify behavior

Additional details

replaceTrack operates "without renegotiation".

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Clarify replaceTrack never triggers renegotiation.

items.content_html:
When you first come across Promises, Asynchronous APIs, and the concept of Zalgo it is quite unusual so the concept needs to be properly framed upon first introduction.

This fix resolves bug #24441

Description

Add clarification and framing to the concept of Zalgo with respect to Promises.

Motivation

Myself, a newcomer to the topic, did not realise that Zalgo was an accepted term in this sphere and that the personal blog was actually the authoritative source for the concept. It felt like an authoritative site deferring to a personal blog and leveraging an internet meme (Zalgo). So my first impressions were incorrect and this change restores proper framing of the concept.

Additional details

#24441

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #24441
items.title: Clarify what is Zalgo

items.content_html:
Description

The regex is not really needed. Added a new comment.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Improve examples

items.content_html:
This is part of #openwebdocs/project#152.

The LinkStyle mixin adds a sheet property. All three browser engines have implemented it for ages.

This PR:

  • Update ProcessingInstruction.sheet that did exist but was slightly incorrect (it returns a StyleSheet object and not a string.
  • Add it to the list of properties on ProcessingInstruction
  • Add the missing HTMLLinkElement.sheet
  • Add the missing HTMLStyleElement.sheet

I kept the examples very simple as this is not very suitable for a live example.
items.title: Document LinkStyle mixin

items.content_html:
Description

In Chrome 111, some changes have been made to the Declarative Shadow DOM proposal, to better support streaming Declarative Shadow DOM.

While I don't think it is the right time to provide complete documentation of Declarative Shadow DOM on MDN (none of the subfeatures are in a spec yet), we do already mention the <template> element's shadowroot attribute, which has been changed to shadowrootmode by the new set of changes.

This PR updates that detail on the <template> page, and makes sure that the latest developer.chrome.com post is linked to for up-to-date information on this proposal. This way it is on the map on MDN, so developers can still discover it up until the time it is full documented on MDN.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Update template element shadowroot attribute to shadowrootmode

items.content_html:
FF111 supports RTCInboundRtpStreamStats.trackIdentifier. This adds a short description in the parent document - I didn't create a full property document, because there isn't that much that needs to be said here about the property. I'm also hoping that this will eventually not be a dictionary - in which case not having a lot of unnecessary information would be good.

In addition this adds a release note and also marks up another member trackid as obsoleted - as per the spec.

There is quite a bit more work required for this page, but it will follow more testing and BCD work.

Other docs work can be tracked in #24397
items.title: FF111 supports RTCInboundRtpStreamStats.trackIdentifier

items.content_html:
This was a guide. Now it's a proper filter page. Creating a guide to filter and backdrop filter in another PR.

Only one file changed
23 images deleted. one renamed.
items.title: CSS property page: filter

items.content_html:
FF111 adds support in FF111 for OPFS "by default". This removes the experimental features record added in 110 and adds the information to the release note.

This could wait a bit before being merged since FF110 only gets released today. I think it doesn't matter so much though - as FF111 is available so there is no particular benefit in knowing that FF110 could also do this in nightly.

Other docs work for this can be tracked in #24388
items.title: FF111 RelNote: OPFS released + Remove from Expr. Features

items.content_html:
Description

This PR adds content for the new features related to the Resizable ArrayBuffer and growable SharedArrayBuffer Stage 3 draft, which was implemented in Chrome 111+.

See my research document for exact details of what has been added, and other required work.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #24369
items.title: Add docs for resizable ArrayBuffer and growable SAB

items.content_html:
Hello, I am studying Speed Index right now and I came across this Glossary Definition. I thought that it could be slightly improved, with a little context about why this metric exists, and if it is appropriate to link to the two major projects using the metric in their audits.

I also think visually the image is large for the entry, so I opted to put all the text above the image with a description to further help.

Hope this proposed change resonates. I believe the information is correct at least, style wise maybe an improvement.

Description

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Reword/restyle Glossary Definition for Speed Index

items.content_html:
This performs some formatting of the GitHub Actions workflows to help ensure more standard-looking formatting. Additionally, this renames a few workflow jobs so they don't all have the same name.

Note: I found we have three labeler workflows (minus the rebase-needed workflow), maybe we should consolidate them?
items.title: refactor(github-actions): Format and rename workflow jobs

items.content_html: The description of coarse and fine pointers did not provide examples, so the meaning of those terms was a bit vague and ambiguous. This change includes some concrete examples to help readers get a better sense of what an "accurate pointing device" can mean.
items.title: css/@media/pointer: give examples of coarse and fine pointers
